blog.name: agameoftragedy
blog.title: Blame GRRM
blog.description: I used to be at least 10% more normal before I read those books. Now everything's Theon Greyjoy (and Robb Stark... and Ramsay Bolton) and everything is awful in a wonderful, wonderful way. My main blog is MzyraJ if you want more of me for some reason.

summary: How I see SanSan’s end game
title: How I see SanSan’s end game
body:
Listening to the last Not a Cast podcast re Sansa II and it got me thinking about what I see happening with Sansa and Sandor.

I feel like in a meta sense they do at least need to meet again, they’ve been so integral to each other’s development that surely they should see how they’ve affected each other.

I’m not sure I can see a formal romantic and sexual relationship though. I’ve seen old quotes of GRRM’s talking about societal structure and how class really mattered and had consequences, and like… Sandor Clegane is not in Sansa Stark’s league, societally speaking. She is the eldest daughter of a lord paramount, whose line goes back thousands of years, and she herself is a good catch on a personal level. He is the second son of… basically a landed knight whose (great?)grandfather was a kennelmaster. He wasn’t even the heir, but he’s likely to have lost all claim to that land now anyway. Now he’s just a guy, not even a knight, and while she’s wanted for potential regicide, she’d probably still be accepted as the Stark heir by the people of the North (because they hate the Boltons and they mostly think her brothers are dead).

Which means something unusual would have to happen to their statuses to put them in a situation where they could be together. If Sansa abandoned her highborn and Stark identity entirely… but that seems completely antithetical to all the identity discussions and Stark regathering. And even if Sandor managed to become greatly landed, it would probably be a Littlefinger-having-Harrenhal situation; the nobility would still look down on him.

Now, if Sansa became Queen of the North, or whatever, then she might have the prerogative to marry whomever she wishes - but again, that seems antithetical to what gets discussed with Dany and Stannis; the monach belongs to their people, and it is more important that they do things to serve their people than their personal own desires. I can’t see any way in which marrying Sandor Clegane would be beneficial to any people Sansa could be Queen of. It would be far more important to secure alliances and peace for her kingdom than be with the guy she fantasises about.

The only other societal shift could be if the Long Night kills off so many people and disrupts society so much that, sure, a highborn lady can marry the son of a landed knight - at least he’s not a peasant.


And besides that I find all that unlikely, I also have a preferred scenario; courtly love, which we haven’t seen a lot of. He will be the True Knight (whether or not he is knighted) to her True Lady/Queen, the Aemon the Dragonknight to her Queen Naerys. She will be able to trust him completely, because he would never forsake her, because she would never ask anything dishonourable of him (perhaps he finally gets knighted because he knows a knighthood from (a knight of) Sansa Stark is actually worth a damn). They can be the prime example of how all of that should work, reclaiming it, ruling through love and honour, not fear and blood.

I don’t know, maybe that’s too hopeful an ending, but I just feel like it fits the themes and I would like some happiness to the endings.
body_abstract: Listening to the last Not a Cast podcast re Sansa II and it got me thinking about what I see happening with Sansa and Sandor.

summary: Sansa Stark, the Badass of Winterfell
title: Sansa Stark, the Badass of Winterfell
body:
There are many things I want from Game of Thrones’ Season 8, but I don’t see this often mentioned:

When Varys finds out that Sansa Stark defeated Littlefinger.

I just want one shot of him going “Oh shit, this girl’s good!”

reblog.comment:
There are many things I want from Game of Thrones’ Season 8, but I don’t see this often mentioned:

summary: what do you think of sansa/willas? personally i don't see the appeal. the tyrells are snakes, benefitting from the lannister...
question: what do you think of sansa/willas? personally i don't see the appeal. the tyrells are snakes, benefitting from the lannister regime that brought so much pain to sansa. they only want tyrell children to control winterfell. also anyone proclaimed to be a decent man in asoiaf must have serious flaws imo
answer: same. it’s vanilla tbh since we don’t see them interacting. i personally have a wish to see the tyrells lose and i hope they’re not one of the houses surviving the long night.

reblog.comment: same. it’s vanilla tbh since we don’t see them interacting. i personally have a wish to see the tyrells lose and i hope they’re not one of the houses surviving the long night.

trail.content_raw: same. it’s vanilla tbh since we don’t see them interacting. i personally have a wish to see the tyrells lose and i hope they’re not one of the houses surviving the long night.

make me choose ♥ sansa in s2-s4 or sansa in s5-s7 | asked by @wolfsansastark 

 The northern girl. Winterfell's daughter. We...
caption:
make me choose ♥ sansa in s2-s4 or sansa in s5-s7 | asked by @wolfsansastark

The northern girl. Winterfell’s daughter. We heard she killed the king with a spell, and afterward changed into a wolf with big leather wings like a bat, and flew out a tower window.

summary: Se c'è una cosa che non sopporto è innalzare una delle sorelle Stark rispetto all'altra. Che sia Sansa o Arya la preferita, si...
body:
Se c'è una cosa che non sopporto è innalzare una delle sorelle Stark rispetto all'altra. Che sia Sansa o Arya la preferita, si tenderà a far vedere come una, sia migliore dell'altra.

Beh, non lo sono. Può piacerti una più dell'altra, trovarti più emotivamente coinvolta e quindi spingerti a fare il tifo per una, piuttosto che sulla sorella. Ma la migliore? Non esiste.

Quello a cui mi sto riferendo, prende piede dall'ipotesi che il viaggio delle due Stark fosse stato invertito: Sansa in fuga e Arya rimasta prigioniera ad Approdo del Re. Mentre Sansa sarebbe morta di stenti lungo la strada, Arya ovviamente non avrebbe avuto problemi a corte, perché quando serve, sa come ci si comporta.

Ora, questa idea nasconde al suo interno un implicazione precisa: Sansa è una incapace, viziata e snob e quindi non può sopravvivere lungo la via, mentre Arya poiché dotata sia di istinto di sopravvivenza sia di maniere, invece si.

Riesco infatti a vedere Arya, la stessa Arya che ha colpito Joffrey al Tridente, rimanere calma, cortese e paziente mentre la picchiano, la insultano o mettono in scena la morte di Robb con i nani. Come no!

Inoltre questa idea danneggia anche la chiusura della settima stagione, dove finalmente con il discorso “non sarei mai sopravvissuta a quello che hai sopportato tu”, le due sorella riconoscono ognuna, il valore dell'altra.

Ah no dimenticavo, Arya vale di più!

Quello a cui mi sto riferendo, prende piede dall'ipotesi che il viaggio delle due Stark fosse stato invertito: Sansa in fuga e Arya rimasta prigioniera ad Approdo del Re. Mentre Sansa sarebbe morta di stenti lungo la strada, Arya ovviamente non avrebbe avuto problemi a corte, perché quando serve, sa come ci si comporta.

Ora, questa idea nasconde al suo interno un implicazione precisa: Sansa è una incapace, viziata e snob e quindi non può sopravvivere lungo la via, mentre Arya poiché dotata sia di istinto di sopravvivenza sia di maniere, invece si.

Riesco infatti a vedere Arya, la stessa Arya che ha colpito Joffrey al Tridente, rimanere calma, cortese e paziente mentre la picchiano, la insultano o mettono in scena la morte di Robb con i nani. Come no!

Inoltre questa idea danneggia anche la chiusura della settima stagione, dove finalmente con il discorso “non sarei mai sopravvissuta a quello che hai sopportato tu”, le due sorella riconoscono ognuna, il valore dell'altra.

Ah no dimenticavo, Arya vale di più!

blog.title: One by one the penguins steal my sanity
